definition: lit. with swords drawn and bows bent (idiom); fig. a state of mutual hostility/at daggers drawn
double-edged sword/CL:口[kou3],把[ba3]/classifier for blows of a sword
to pull up/to pull out/to draw out by suction/to select/to pick/to stand out (above level)/to surpass/to seize
crossbow
surname Zhang
to open up/to spread/sheet of paper/classifier for flat objects, sheet/classifier for votes

sentences.english: At the end of Jiang’s second term, Beijingand Taipei wereon a collision course.
sentences.chinese: 在江第二屆任期之末，北京與臺北劍拔弩張。

sentences.english: Even the Thai-Cambodian troops on both sides are at daggers drawn as people think.
sentences.chinese: 就連泰柬兩邊的駐軍也沒有人們想象的那樣劍拔弩張。

sentences.english: So are US forces in the region.
sentences.chinese: 美國在該地區的力量也劍拔弩張。

sentences.english: The two agendas sit in tension, but they are not contradictory.
sentences.chinese: 雖說這兩個政黨劍拔弩張，但是他們並不矛盾。

sentences.english: The North and South were at loggerheads.
sentences.chinese: 南北雙方形成了劍拔弩張的緊張局勢。

sentences.english: Buyers and sellers is mutual on credit grade issue diversionary , at swords' points.
sentences.chinese: 買賣雙方在信用評級問題上互相牽制，劍拔弩張。
